content.question:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

The following stemplot shows the swimming speeds, in kilometers per hour (<math alttext="k m slash h"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>km/h</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), for a random sample of <math alttext="31"><mstyle><mrow><mn>31</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> emperor penguins.

(a) The mean of the sample is <math alttext="9.771 kilometers per hour"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>9.771 km/h</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the standard deviation is <math alttext="0.944 kilometers per hour"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.944 km/h</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Construct and interpret a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the mean swimming speed of all emperor penguins in the population.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

The following stemplot shows the swimming speeds, in kilometers per hour (<math alttext="k m slash h"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>km/h</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>), for a random sample of <math alttext="31"><mstyle><mrow><mn>31</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> emperor penguins.

(a) The mean of the sample is <math alttext="9.771 kilometers per hour"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>9.771 km/h</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the standard deviation is <math alttext="0.944 kilometers per hour"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>0.944 km/h</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Construct and interpret a <math alttext="95"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the mean swimming speed of all emperor penguins in the population.
(b) Can the estimate of the mean swimming speed be generalized to all types of penguins? Explain your reasoning.

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate inference method for confidence intervals.
